sp.p: Comes up to him , in a low voice .Cut it , my dear lad . Cut it ! That 's understood ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes , of course . Well , good-night , Dolly , once more .She does n't reply .Oh well , if you 're going on the rampage —Goes off muttering .Exit .Infernal nuisance — night like this ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Lucas has offended me very much . I do n't wish to speak of it . The PROFESSOR enters at back .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Well , who was the victor ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: The Professor won all four games .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I ascribe the increased accuracy of my stroke at billiards to my increased nerve force , now I have made Pableine my staple article of diet in place of meat .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Flies to the gray matter , eh ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Instantaneously .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Good stuff !

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I hope you 'll try it . Shall I send a tin to your room ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Will you ? That will be kind ! CRIDDLE appears at door .

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: I 've put the spirits in the hall , sir .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You can take them away , Criddle . In the future we shall not require spirits at night , only soda water and tea .

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Exit .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Who has been sitting wearily on sofa , rises .Well , I 'm going to bed .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You forget , dear .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What ?HARRY taps the writing-desk .Oh , my dear Harry , we wo n't go into them to-night .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes , my dear , if you please .Very firmly . DOLLY makes an impatient gesture and pouts .Please do n't look like that . If I 'm to help you in paying off these bills , it must be to-night , or not at all .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Sits down wearily .Oh , very well , but ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Taking out watch .Five minutes past my usual hour .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Renie has one of her bad headaches , so I 've put her in the spare room .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Thank you . I 'm afraid she 's a little wilful . I can never get her to see that life can yield us no real satisfaction unless we regulate all our actions to the most minute point . Good-night .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Shaking hands .Good-night .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Good-night , Telfer .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Shaking hands .Good-night .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Good-night , Harry .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Shaking hands .Good-night , Dad .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: To DOLLY .Night-night , dear .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Kissing him .Night-night , Dad .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Has been waiting at door .I might perhaps show you the precise way of mixing the Pableine .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: That would be kind ! What 's the dose ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Two teaspoonfuls . On certain occasions I have taken as much as four tablespoonfuls .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Was n't that rather — going it ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: No . It 's quite tasteless , except for a very slight beany flavor .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Sounds just the thing for a New Year 's drink , to brace up good resolutions . Come along ! I 'll have a regular night-cap of it .

div.stage: Exeunt MATT and PROFESSOR .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Now we can have our cosy half hour .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ye-es . I 've had an awful evening with Lucas . Do n't you think ——?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , my darling . You put it off after tea ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: But our heads will be so much clearer in the morning ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Very solemnly and severely .My darling , remember what Pilcher said about procrastination . And remember our resolutions last night . If we break them on the first night of the year , where shall we be on the thirty-first of December ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I 'm horribly fagged .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Conquer it ! Think how delightful it will be to put your head on the pillow to-night , without a single anxiety , without a single thought ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Except my gratitude to you !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Come , dear , no time like the present !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Jumps up very briskly .No time like the present !Looking at him with great admiration .Oh , Harry , what a dear , kind , good husband you 've always been to me !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Have I , my darling ?Modestly .I 've done my best ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: How I must have tried you !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , dear — at least a little sometimes .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: When I think what patience you 've had with me , and never reproached me ——

lg.l: Well , not often . We 've had our little tiffs — That day at

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Do n't speak of it ! I was to blame ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , dear , I can n't let you accuse yourself . I was quite in the wrong .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , dear , it was my fault entirely !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well , we wo n't quarrel about that . Now these bills ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: And what good pals we 've been !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Kissing her .And always shall be .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Hugging him .Oh , you dear !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Now , business , business !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Going up to writing-desk .What a lucky woman I am !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Seated at table .Bring them all .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Has opened desk and taken up some bills — she looks round dubiously at HARRY .What a splendid thing it must be to be a husband and have it in your power to make your wife adore you , by simply paying a few bills .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes — bring them all .She comes down with a bundle of about fifteen , hands them to him .Is this all ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: All , of any importance .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I want to see them all .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: So you shall , but we 'll go through these first , becauselamelyif you want to ask any questions we can settle them on the spot , can n't we ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Reading from the bill .Looks up .Maison Récamier , Court and artistic millinery . By Jove !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: One , two , three , four , five , six , seven , eight , nine — nine hats !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Different kinds of hats .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yedda straw hat , four guineas , ostrich feather ruffle , twelve pounds ten ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: That was the one — you remember — when I came into the room you said , “ Stay there ! Just as you are ! I must kiss you ! ”

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes , but twelve pounds ten — Moss green chip hat , four , fourteen , six . Heliotrope velvet toque ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: That 's the dear little toque you admire so much !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Do I ? Six guineas ! Dear little toque ! Hat in white Tegal with plumes of Nattier Bleu — fifteen guineas — Fifteen guineas ? !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: With plumes ! Of Nattier Bleu !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: But fifteen guineas !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Oh , the woman 's a fearful swindler ! But what are you to do with such people ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: With bill .Total , sixty-four , seven , six . And I get my one silk topper a year , at a guinea , and three and six for doing it up . Total for me , one , four , six . Total for you ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: My dear Harry , do n't make absurd comparisons !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Takes another bill .John Spearman , artistic gown maker , ball gowns , reception gowns , race gowns — Good heavens !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Total , five hundred and fifty-six pounds — that can n't be right !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Frightened .No , it can n't be ! Add it up !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Reading .Tea gown of chiffon taffeta —

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: The one I took to Folkestone , you remember ?

div.stage: With a little attempt at a kiss .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Gently repulsing her .No , I do n't .She puts her arms round his neck ; he gently pushes her aside .Business first , please .Reads .Gown of white cloth with Postillion coat of Rose du Barri silk , motifs of silver , forty-five guineas ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You wo n't grumble at that , for when I first put it on , you stood and looked at me and said , “ I want to know how it is , Doll , that the moment a dress gets on to your shoulders , it seems to brisk up , and be as cocky and proud of itself —— ”

div.stage: Again attempting to embrace him .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Again repulsing her .Yes , well now I do know ! Jolly proud and cocky your dresses ought to feel at this price !Reads .“ Evening cloak of strawberry satin charmeuse , trimmed silk passementerie , motifs and fringed stoles of dull gold embroidery , thirty-five guineas . ” What 's a motif ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: It 's a trimming — a lot of little touches — a sort of — a — a — a —making a little descriptive gesturea suggestion — a motif ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: And Mr. John Spearman 's motif is that I should pay him five hundred and fifty-six pounds . Well , I do n't like Mr. John Spearman 's motifs , and I 'm not going to fall in with them .Puts the bill on the table rather angrily , takes up another , reads .“ Artistic lingerie ! ” I wonder why all these people call themselves artists ! “ Underwear of daintiness and distinction . ”

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Well , you 've always praised ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes . In future , I 'm going to be very careful what articles of your dress I praise . “ Three pairs of blue silk garters , forty-five shillings . ”She has settled herself in the armchair , looking a little sulky and obstinate , leaning back and pettishly swinging one leg over the other .What have you got to say to that ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Garters are necessary .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes , but why three ? And why blue silk ? Why do n't you speak ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: The garters can speak for themselves !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Very well . Garters that can speak for themselves can pay for themselves !Dashes the bill on the table , takes up another . Reading .Three bottles coeur de Janette — three bottles Souffle de Marguerite — fifteen pounds for scent — and I have to smoke sixpenny cigars ! And sometimes only fourpenny !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Well , if you will smoke those horrid strong things you can n't wonder I have to disinfect the house for you .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Disinfect the house for me ! You 'll very soon disinfect the house of me !Glances through the remaining bills , groans , puts them on the table , and walks about in despair . DOLLY rises and is going off .Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: To bed .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Stopping her .No ! Now we 've begun , we 'll go through to the bitter end , if you please . I want you to explain ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: My dear Harry , it will be quite useless for me to try to explain in your present state ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Getting furious .In my present state ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Dancing about the room and shouting !——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I 'm not shouting !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You 're not shouting ? !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , and if I am , is n't it enough to make a man shout when his wife —— MATT appears at the door in his dressing-gown and slippers .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Excuse my interrupting . But you know my room is just above this , and if you could manage to pitch your voices in rather a softer key ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: By Jove , I 'd forgotten ! We were getting a little noisy . I 'm awfully sorry .

lg.l: Do n't mention it ! The Professor gave me rather a stiff go of his
Pableine , and I fancy it has n't agreed with me
I can n't get a wink of sleep . Is there a spoonful of whiskey about ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: On the sideboard in the dining-room .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Thankee .Tapping his chest .Harry , when you get over fifty , do n't change your nightcap , or any of your other bad habits .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I wo n't . Now , Dolly ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Anxiously .You wo n't perhaps be very long now ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , we 'd nearly finished ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Nothing serious , I hope ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Harry does n't approve of my using scent .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Not in pailfuls . Certainly not .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I had three small bottles ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Exit .Montaigne says that the sweetest perfume a woman can have , is to have none at all .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Now , my darling , we shall best arrive at an understanding if we avoid all temper , and discuss it in a calm , business-like way .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: A little frightened .Ye-es ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Very well then , bring up your chair , and let us go into it , figure by figure , item by item , and see how we stand .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ye-es .Bringing a chair a little way .Harry , you are n't going to be as business-like as all that ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: As all what ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I can n't discuss it while you keep me at a distance !Suddenly rushes at him , seats herself on his knee , puts his arm round her waist , kisses him .There ! now I feel I can discuss it thoroughly .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Very wellkisses her, so long as we do discuss it thoroughly .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I began to get quite frightened of you , Mr. Jobling .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Jobling ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: The man Mr. Pilcher had to get a money-box for , because he swore at his wife !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , yes .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You got so angry — and shouted ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well , there was no reason for that , especially as getting out of temper is the one thing I 'm quite resolved to conquer this New Year ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Kissing him .Do n't forget that !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Kisses her .Now , business , business !Takes up a bill .What have we here ? Carchet , gantier et bonnetier , artiste — Hillo , here 's another artist ! In stockings this time .Suddenly .I say !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Frightened .Eh ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Points to an item in bill .Come now , Dolly — this is really too bad — this really is too bad !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Frightened .What ? !

div.stage: Getting off his knee .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: One dozen pairs best silk hose , with clocks ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes — how much does that come to ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Eleven pounds two ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: It does seem rather a high price , but ——

div.stage: Drawing up her dress and showing an inch or two of silk stocking .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You 're wearing them about the house ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I can n't go about the house without stockings . And I put them on for your especial benefit .He utters a contemptuous exclamation .They 're a lovely quality ——

div.stage: Drawing up her dress an inch or two higher .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I daresay .Turning away .I 'm not going to admire your stockings , or your ostrich ruffles , or your blue silk garters , or your motifs , or anything that is yours ! It 's too expensive !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Dress an inch higher , looking down at her stockings .It 's the clocks you have to pay for ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I beg your pardon , it 's the clocks I have n't got to pay for ! And do n't mean to — if I can help it . Idiotic thing to go and put clocks on stockings —mutteringdamned silly idiotic ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ah !Goes to table , brings the hospital box and puts it in front of him .Double fine this time .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Naughty swear word , and getting out of temper .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh well —fumbling in his pocketI did say d ——, but I did n't get out of temper !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You did n't get out of temper ?! ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Not at all . I 'm quite calm .Sulkily puts a shilling in the box .There !Seats himself at table .Now we 'll go quietly and methodically through the remainder ——Taking up a bill , looks at it , exclaims .Good heavens !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Good heavens what ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: In a low exhausted tone with groans .Good heavens ! Good heavens ! It 's absolutely useless — Good heavens !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Coming up , looking over .But what is it ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Points to bill .Four more hats ! Nine on the other bill — four more here . Thirteen hats .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , one was a toque .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: But can you explain ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes . You said yourself that Madame Récamier was horribly expensive , so I left her and went to Jacquelin 's — just to save your pocket ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Never save my pocket again , please .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Very well , I wo n't .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , I daresay you wo n't , but I shall ! I shall draw the strings very tightly in future . Save my pocket !He is walking about distractedly .Groans .Save my pocket .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Now , Harry , it 's useless to take it in this way — you knew when you married me I had n't got the money sense ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Groans .I had n't got any sense at all !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Very likely not . But try and have a little now . What have I done ? Run a little into debt , solely to please you .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes ; well , now run out of it , and I shall be better pleased still .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: After all , running into debt is a positive virtue beside the things that some wives do !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , it 's a positive virtue , is it ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: A husband is very lucky when his wife spends most of her time running up a few bills . It keeps her out of mischief . I 'm sure you ought to feel very glad that I 'm a little extravagant !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , I am ! I am ! I 'm delighted !

div.stage: He sits at table , takes out a pencil , hurriedly puts down the amounts of the various bills — she creeps up behind him .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What are you doing ?

lg.l: I 'm totting up to see how lucky I am ! Forty-one , one , six ——

lg.stage: Has crept up behind him , puts her arms round his neck .
lg.l: Harry , will you take my advice ——?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: It 's past eleven .

div.stage: Trying to take the pencil out of his hand .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Disengaging her arms , speaking very sternly .Will you have the goodness to let me have all your bills , so that I may know what help I shall need from my banker ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Harry , you do n't mean that ? Oh , that 's absurd with our income !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Will you have the goodness to do as I say , and at once , please ?He is dotting down figures . She stands still in the middle of the room .Did you hear me ?

div.stage: She bursts into tears . He turns round and shows symptoms of relenting towards her , but steels himself and turns to the bills . She bursts into renewed tears . He goes on figuring .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Piteously .Harry ! Harry !Goes up to him and plucks his sleeve .Harry !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well ?

div.stage: He turns and looks at her , is about to yield , but resists , turns away from her , settles resolutely to his figures .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: And on the first night of the New Year , too ! Just as we were going to be so happy ! Harry !Holds out her arms appealingly .Harry !HARRY suddenly turns round and clasps her .How could you be so unkind to me ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Was I ? I did n't mean to be . Now ! Dry your tears , and help me reckon this up ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ye-es .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: But first of all let me have the remainder of the bills ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: At once , my darling — it 's getting late .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes .Goes up to desk .You wo n't reproach me ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Of course I wo n't .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I can bear anything except your reproaches . Promise you wo n't reproach me .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I wo n't , unless ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Unless what ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: It 's something too awful .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Oh , it is n't . Not at all . Not at all .Goes up to the desk , brings down about ten more bills with great affected cheerfulness .There ! You see , it 's nothing .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Hastily looking at the totals .Nothing ? You call these nothing !! ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Nothing to speak about — nothing awful !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Good heavens ! How any woman with the least care for her husband , or her home ——looking at one total after anotherhow any woman with the least self-respect ——DOLLY goes to him , puts her arms round him , tries to embrace — he repulses her .No , please . I 've had enough of that old dodge .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Dodge !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I remember that last two hundred pounds and how you sweedled me out of it !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Sweedled ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes ! Sweedled !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: There 's no such word !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , but there 's the thing ! As most husbands know .Referring to one bill after another , picking out items .Lace coat , hand-made ! En-tout-cas , studded cabochons of lapis lazuli — studded cabochons — studded cabochons !

lg.stage: Has quietly seated herself , and is looking at the ceiling .
lg.l: Could n't you manage to pitch your voice in rather a softer key ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Comes angrily down to her , bills in hand , speaks in a whisper , very rapidly and fiercely .Yes ! And I say that a woman who goes and runs up bills like these ,dashing the back of one hand against the bills in the otherwhile her husband is smoking threepenny cigars , will very soon bring herself and him to one of those new palatial workhouses where , thank heaven , the cuisine and appointments are now organized with a view of providing persons of your tastes with every luxury at the ratepayers ’ expense .Returns angrily to the bills , turns them over .Irish lace bolero !Turns to another .Fur motor coat , fifty-five guineas ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Calmly gazing at the ceiling .You told me to look as smart as Mrs. Colefield .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Not at that price ! If I 'd known what that motor tour would cost by Jove ! I 'd ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You 're getting noisy again . You 'll wake my father .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: He ought to be waked ! He ought to know what his daughter is saddling me with .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Very well , if you do n't care how shabby I look ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: My dear Harry , do you suppose we shall ever agree as to what constitutes shabbiness ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , I 'm hanged if we ever shall !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Then suppose we drop the subject . For the future I shall endeavor to please you entirely .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , you will ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: By dressing so that you 'll be ashamed to be seen in the same street with me . I shall make myself a perfect fright — a perfect dowdy — a perfect draggletail !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Then I shall not be seen in the same street with you .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You wo n't ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , my dear . Make no mistake about that !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You 'll be seen with somebody else , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Very likely .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Have you met Miss Smithson again ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Not since the last time .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Have you seen her since we were at Folkestone ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: What 's that to do with your bills ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: A great deal . That night at dinner she told you her dress allowance was a hundred and twenty a year , and you said you wished she 'd give me a few lessons in economy .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I did not .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Pardon me , you did !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Pardon me , I did not . I said she might give some women a lesson in economy .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You did not ! I heard every word of your conversation , and you distinctly asked her to give me , your wife , a few lessons in economy .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I 'll swear I did n't !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ask my father ! He was there .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Very well ! I 'll ask him the first thing in the morning .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , to-night ! You 've accused me of deliberately saying what is n't true , and I ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I have not !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes , you have . And I insist on having it cleared up to-night ! I do n't suppose he 's asleep ! Fetch him down !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Exit .Very well ! I will fetch him down !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Paces furiously up and down .Me ! Lessons in economy ! Lessons in economy ! Me ! Lessons in economy ! Re-enter HARRY .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: He 'll be down in a minute ! Meantime ,very angryI want to know what any woman in this world wants with two dozen cache corsets ?

div.stage: Banging his free hand on the bills .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: We 'll clear up Miss Smithson first ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , we will not clear up Miss Smithson ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Because you can n't clear up Miss Smithson ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I can clear up Miss Smithson ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You cannot clear up Miss Smithson —— MATT appears at door in dressing-gown , rubbing his eyes and looking very sleepy . Dad , you remember Miss Smithson ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Coming in , very sleepy .Smithson ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: The girl at the hotel at Folkestone , that Harry paid so much attention to .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I paid no more attention to Miss Smithson than was absolutely necessary . Did I , Mr. Barron ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Oh ! Oh ! Dad , you remember ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Not for the moment ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Not the disgraceful way Harry — there 's no other word — carried on !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I did not carry on — Mr. Barron , I appeal to you .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Dad !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: My dear , I certainly did not notice ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , he was far too careful to let anyone notice it , except his own wife !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You lay your life when I do carry on my wife will be the last person I shall allow to notice it !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I daresay ! Dad , did you hear that ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: That 's what I want to know !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Who is Miss Smithson ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Surely you remember that lanky girl ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Miss Smithson is not lanky ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Not lanky ? Not lanky ?! You can n't have any eyes ——!

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: That 's what I 've often thought ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Explodes .Oh ! Oh ! Dad !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Come , Harry , let 's clear this up .Suddenly .Smithson ? Oh yes ! The girl who sat on your left at your dinner party ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: That 's the one !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I should call her a trifle lanky , Harry .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: A trifle ? Well , never mind ! You remember that dinner party ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Cautiously .Ye-es .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You remember how she waited for a lull in the talk , and then she said with that silly , simpering , appealing look ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Miss Smithson 's look is not silly or simpering .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Well , it 's appealing , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: With a little chuckle .Oh , yes , it 's appealing .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Enraged .Oh ! Dad !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Quiets her .Shush !— What did she say ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: She said with a very marked glance at me , “ My dress allowance is a hundred and twenty a year , and I do n't understand how any reasonable woman can wish for more ! ” What do you think of that ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Well , if she did say that , and if she glanced at you , it ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: It was n't very nice of her .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Nice ? It was an insult ! A direct , intentional , abominable insult , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Yes , yes , decidedly , under the circumstances ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: And Harry ought to have resented it ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: At his own dinner table he could n't , could he ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ! At least , if he could n't resent it , he ought to have shown that he resented it . Instead of that , he actually asked her to give me a few lessons in economy !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I did not !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Pardon me , you did ! Me ! his wife ! Lessons in economy !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: And a thundering good thing if she had given you a few before you ran up these bills !

div.stage: Dashes his hand on to the bills .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: There ! You hear ? !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Come , Harry , you ought n't to have asked another woman to give your wife lessons in economy .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I did n't !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Dad ! You were there ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Yes , but I do n't quite remember ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You do n't remember ?! Surely you can remember a simple thing like that when your own daughter tells you it was so !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Now , Harry , what did you really say to Miss Smithson ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I said she might give some women a lesson in economy .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Not meaning Dolly ?

div.stage: Giving him a wink to say “ No . ”

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No-o .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Then whom did he mean ? Lessons in economy ? Whom could he mean if he did n't mean me ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Just so !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ah ! There ! You see , he owns it !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No , no , I 'm sure he does n't mean it ! Did you , Harry ?

div.stage: Winking at HARRY .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Then will he please say what he really does mean ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Now , Harry , what do you really mean ?

lg.l: Well , you remember that night of the dinner party at

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Cautiously .Ye-es .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: After they 'd all gone you and I went into the smoking-room , did n't we ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Cautiously .Ye-es .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: And you said , “ Doll 's in one of her high gales again ! ”

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: High gales ? !Indignant .Father ! You did n't say that ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No , no , my dear ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Excuse me , those were your exact words . High gales !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I do n't remember .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , you do n't remember anything .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You said , “ What on earth was up between her and Miss Smithson at dinner ? ”

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You see ! That proves exactly what I said !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , by Jove , it proves that your father noticed what a confounded , cussed ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Go on ! Go on ! Say it !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Shush ! Shush ! Well , Harry , what did you say ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well , not wishing to give Dolly away ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! Not wishing to give me away !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Not then ! But , by Jove , if any decent chap were to come along now ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Exploding .There ! There !To MATT .And you sit there and hear my own husband insult me in my own house !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No ! No !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: But there you sit ! There you sit !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Jumps up fiercely .Now , Harry !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Fiercely .Well , now , Mr. Barron ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Why do n't you defend me ? Why do n't you demand an apology ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: For everything ! For to-night ! For that night at Folkestone !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: That night at Folkestone ! Why , your father was quite on my side ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: He was n't ; were you , Dad ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No — no .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: What ?Fiercely .Do you remember exactly what passed between us in the smoking-room , Mr. Barron ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Then I 'll tell you ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Retreating towards door .No — no — I do n't want to know ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Following him up , shouting a little .You said , “ I know what she 's like in her high gales ! I remember what the little devil was like at home . ”

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Pursuing him up to door .Father ! You did n't say that !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No — no , my darling — quite a mistake — quite a mistake — altogether a mistake .

div.stage: Gets thankfully off at back .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Calls after him .Then why do n't you stay and tell him so !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Shouts after MATT .It 's not a mistake !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Calls after MATT .It 's cowardly of you to leave me here to be insulted .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Goes up to door , shouts .It 's not a mistake ! You patted me on the back and said , “ Poor chap ! Poor chap ! ” You know you did !Closes the door , comes fiercely down to DOLLY .It 's not a mistake ! He could see you had insulted Miss Smithson .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I had not insulted her ! I was far too civil to her , considering that the next evening you took her out on the Leas , when you ought to have been at billiards ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I took her out on the Leas !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ! You were n't in the billiard-room ! So where were you ? Where were you ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I jolly well do n't know , and I — I ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Say it ! Say it !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I damned well do n't care !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ah !

div.stage: She seizes the box , brings it up to him , puts it irritatingly in front of him ; he seizes it , they struggle for it , trying to take it out of each other 's hands ; she screams , he tries to get it ; there is a scuffle round the room ; he tries to rub her knuckles ; she makes a little feint to bite him ; in the struggle the box drops on the floor a little below the table , right .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Jobling ! Jobling ! Jobling !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Now , madam , for the last time , have I all your bills ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Jobling ! Jobling ! Jobling !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Have I all your bills ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Jobling ! Jobling ! Jobling !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Once more , madam , have I all your bills ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , you have n't !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Then please hand them over to me this instant , so that I may take proceedings .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Laughing .Proceedings ! Ha ! Take your proceedings !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: By Jove ! I will take proceedings .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Take them ! Take them !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Walking about furiously with the bills .So this is the way the money goes !Banging the bills .While I have to smoke twopenny cigars ! And can n't get a decent dinner !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You can n't get a decent dinner ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No ! Look at those messes last night . They were n't fit for a cook-shop .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Oh ! Oh ! Oh ! Get a housekeeper ! Get a housekeeper !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: By Jove ! that 's what I mean to do !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Have Miss Smithson ! Send for her to-morrow morning ! I 'll hand her over the keys !

lg.l: And please hand me over the rest of your bills !
The rest of your bills , madam !
lg.stage: DOLLY marches up to the desk .
lg.l: MATT appears at door in dressing-gown .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I can n't get a wink of sleep ——

div.stage: DOLLY takes out about twenty more bills .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I insist on seeing the whole lot ! So there !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Flourishing the bills , strewing them on the floor .Exit .Well there ! And there ! And there ! And there ! Now you 've got the whole lot ! And I hope you 're satisfied . I 'm going into Renie 's room !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I insist on your going through these bills ——
