Take your proceedings , ” HARRY saying , “ I insist on going through the bills to-night ! Do you hear , madam , I insist ! Will you come down and go through these bills , ” etc .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Listens , as their voices die away . When the voices have ceased , he surveys the scene .We 're making a splendid start for the New Year !Sees the box on the floor , picks it up , carefully places it on table and goes off .CURTAIN .A year passes between Acts III and IV .ACT IV .

div.stage: SCENE : The same .
TIME : Afternoon of January 1st , 1908 .
Enter LUCAS , followed by CRIDDLE . LUCAS has his left collar-bone broken , and his arm is strapped across his breast ; his coat is buttoned loosely over the arm , the left sleeve hanging down .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: They 've gone to meet me ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: By the road ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: That 's how I 've missed them . My car broke down the other side of the clump , and so I walked over the fields .

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Yes , sir . I beg pardon , I hope the arm is n't serious .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: No , Criddle . Just serious enough to get me a couple of months ’ leave , so that I could spend the New Year in England .

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: You had it very hot in India , I suppose , sir ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Blazing !

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: We 've got the same old weather here , you see , sir .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Same old weather ! Had any visitors for Christmas , Criddle ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Mr. Barron , of course , and Professor and Mrs. Sturgess .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Same old visitors — same visitors , I should say . Mr. Pilcher still Vicar here , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Yes , sir . He gave us a wonderful sermon at the old year 's service last night .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Same old sermon !

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: No , sir . Not exactly the same sermon , though it had similar points to last year . Ah ! You came over for the old year 's service last year ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes , and a rattling good sermon it was !

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Very powerful and persuading , was n't it , sir ? It even touched me up a bit .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: In what way , Criddle ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: I used to have my ten bob on any horse as I fancied , but I never put a farthing on anything — not even on Sulky Susan for the Oaks .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: You did n't ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: No , and thank God , in a manner of speaking , that I did n't , for she never pulled it off . I owe that to Mr. Pilcher . No , I never touched a thing till the Leger . That reminds me ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: What , Criddle ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Why , last year , after Mr. Pilcher 's sermon , the master had a collecting box , and when he found himself going a bit off the straight he used to put in a shilling or half-a-crown for Mr. Pilcher 's blanket fund ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes , of course ! And Uncle Matt promised him a sovereign for each of us if we had carried out our good resolutions . Is that coming off , Criddle ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: I expect it is , sir . Mr. Pilcher is coming here this afternoon , and the master told me to be sure and find the box before he gets here .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Find the box ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Nobody has seen anything of it for some months . Excuse me , sir , I must look for it .Exit CRIDDLE .LUCAS takes out letter from an unsealed envelope , glances through it , sits at table , takes out pencil , adds a short note , puts letter in envelope , seals it up , puts it in his tail pocket , goes to conservatory , looks in . RENIE enters at door behind him . She starts , as he turns round .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: In a whisper .You 're here already ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes ——

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Your wound ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Much better . Nearly well .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I 'm so glad ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I 'm not . I shall have to cut it back to India directly . Why did n't you answer my last letter ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I did — and tore it up .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Tore it up ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: What 's the use ? I told you last year we could never be anything to each other !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: But you did n't mean it ?

div.stage: He seizes her hand and kisses it several times .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Feebly attempting to withdraw it .Yes — yes , I did . Hush !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Shows her the letter .I want you to read this .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Heard through the door which is open a few inches .Have you found the box , Criddle ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: No , sir . I 've hunted everywhere .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Have another look . We must have it ready for Mr. Pilcher .

sp.speaker: MATT enters
sp.p: Meantime RENIE has crept to upper conservatory door and gone off signing to LUCAS to keep silence . He has taken the letter out of his pocket and held it up for her to see , putting it back before MATT enters .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Ah , Lucas . So you 've got here . Happy New Year !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Happy New Year , Uncle Matt .

div.stage: Cordially shaking hands .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Glad to see you back in England .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Glad to be back !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: How 's the arm ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Splendid — nearly well . Dolly and Harry all right ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: First rate . They 'll be here directly .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: The Sturgesses are here again , Criddle tells me .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Ye-es .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Gray matter still going strong ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Booming .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: How 's Mrs. Sturgess ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: As usual , a little inclined to flop about and play act ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes . Jolly good-looking woman though , eh ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Very . Lucas ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: You 're quite cured , eh ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Cured ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Of your infatuation for her .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Infatuation ? Well , I admired her , and perhaps it was lucky I was ordered out to India ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I managed that for you , my boy .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: You did ! ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Sir John wanted a smart A. D. C ., so I drove over to Aldershot , urged your claims , and got you the appointment .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: So that was why I was packed off . It was you who ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Are n't you thankful I did ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes , much obliged to you , much obliged !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: So you ought to be . And so 's the lady .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Is she ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Yes . When we got your wire yesterday saying you 'd motor down to-day , Dolly had a long talk with her , and the result was she thanked Dolly and me for getting you out of the way and saving her from you .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Did she ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Yes , for twenty minutes . She kissed Dolly , and I think she would have kissed me , only I did n't feel myself quite worthy .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh , so that 's all settled !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: That 's all settled . At least , let 's hope so .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Well , you wo n't come ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: The same old game .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: What same old game ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Why , the same old game !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: You must be judging me by yourself , when you were young .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: My dear boy , that 's just what I am doing . Lucas , there 's not going to be any repetition ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: No — no .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Because it is n't the right thing to do , is it ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Very well then , do n't do it !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I wo n't !Listening .Ah !DOLLY and HARRY 'S voices heard in hallDolly and Harry ! DOLLY and HARRY enter very lovingly .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Hillo , Doll , old girl ! Happy New Year !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Happy New Year , Lu !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Harry , old brick , how goes it ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Splendid !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Happy New Year !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Happy New Year !Looking lovingly at DOLLY .By Jove , Doll , you can foot it .To LUCAS .Doll and I have just raced up from the farm . She licked me ! bless her !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes , because you encouraged me !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Looking at her lovingly and admiringly , kisses her heartily .There are n't many things this little woman can n't do .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: When you encourage me !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , I 'll encourage you !

div.stage: He again kisses her heartily .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well , Lu , old boy , glad to see you home again . Arm pretty bad ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: No , nearly well , unfortunately .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Down for the day ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Well , now my car has broken down , I was wondering if you 'd put me up ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Firmly .No . We shall be pleased for you to stay to dinner .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: There 's the spare room , Doll .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Firmly .No . That may be wanted for Renie or myself .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Half aside to her .I say , not for you , old girl !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh , well , I shall have to get a shake-down at the Red Lion .

div.stage: Enter RENIE at back , still in outdoor clothes .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Happy New Year , Mrs. Sturgess .

div.stage: Shaking hands .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: So sorry to hear of your wound !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh , it 's healed , thank you .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I 'm so glad . Shall you be making a long stay in England ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I fear only a few days longer .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I 'm sorry your visit will be so short . CRIDDLE enters triumphantly with the hospital box which is very mouldy and dusty — he has also duster in his hand .

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: I 've found him , sir —

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Rather mouldy , eh ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Oh , we 'll soon put that to rights , sir .

div.stage: Begins to dust the box carefully .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Looks well for your household discipline here , Harry .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: You 've had no occasion to use him lately .

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: Displaying the box , having carefully dusted it .There he is , sir , Hospital for Incurables ! Nearly as good as new .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Where did you find him ?

sp.speaker: Criddle
sp.p: In the wine-cellar , of all places ! I was getting out a bottle of the sixty-eight port for New Year 's night , and happening to put my hand behind , there he was !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Has a sudden gesture of remembrance .Yes , I remember !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What should incurables be doing in the wine-cellar ?Holds out his hand to CRIDDLE for the box . CRIDDLE , who has been holding it carefully , gives it to MATT . Exit CRIDDLE . MATT gives the box a shake . It rattles as if half full of coins . He shakes it again , more violently ; it rattles again .Internal organs sound healthy . How did he get into the wine-cellar , Harry ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well , Dolly and I had been having a little tiff one morning — nothing serious ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No . When was that ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: March , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: May , I think ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , it was n't that one — Well , never mind , I got so riled at Dolly always poking this box in front of me whenever I happened to — so I thought the wine-cellar would be the safest place for it .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Gives it another rattle .Well , here he is , turned up just at the right moment ! And here you all are , Dolly , Harry , Lucas , Mrs. Sturgess — all clamouring for me to redeem my promise and put in a sovereign for each of you . CRIDDLE appears at door announcing MR. PILCHER . PILCHER enters with four oblong brown paper parcels of equal size . Exit CRIDDLE .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Happy New Year to you all ! Excuse me .Depositing his parcels .My New Year 's gifts to a few of my parishioners !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: New Year 's gifts !

div.stage: Shaking hands .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Happy New Year !

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: How do this morning , Telfer !HARRY nods .Shaking hands .My dear Mrs. Sturgess !

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Happy New Year ! What a lovely sermon you gave us again last night !

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Lovely ! Well , say healthy , bracing .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: A jolly good rouser again . Made me feel — well ——

div.stage: Gives himself a shake .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Ah , Captain Wentworth , happy New Year !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Shaking hands .Happy New Year !

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: I heard you were wounded ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh , that 's done with .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: We were just talking about our New Year 's inquest ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Inquest ? !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Into the characters of Dolly and Harry and ——

div.stage: Glancing at RENIE and LUCAS .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Oh , please do n't talk about inquests . Nobody 's character is dead here .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I hope not ! We shall see ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Uncle , you do n't really mean ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: It was a bona fide bargain on my side , but if you wish to avoid any awkward little exposures , or if Mr. Pilcher will kindly waive his claims to my contributions ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: I 'm afraid I can n't . I have come here for the express purpose of bearing away my trophy — Ah !Seeing box on table , takes it , gives it a shake ; his features assume a pleasant smile .It seems to have proved a very wholesome household regulator .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes , by Jove ! It had n't been in the house twenty-four hours before I put in a sovereign .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: A sovereign ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: The first night of last year Dolly and I had a little tiff — nothing serious — and so the next morning I made it up and — did n't I , Dolly ?——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You did ! And paid my bills like a lamb , you dear !

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: And put in a sovereign ?Rattles the box again .I wo n't say “ Do n't have any more household tiffs , ” but I will say “ Do n't omit to liquidate them . ”Gives the box another rattle .The box must have been in pretty constant use since ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Ye-es . PROFESSOR STURGESS enters at back , with the proofs of his book in his hand .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Happy New Year to you !To LUCAS .How d'ye do ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: First rate . Happy New Year !

div.stage: Shaking hands .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Thank you . An accident ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Bit of one . Getting over it .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: If I might recommend the constant use of Pableine .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh , thanks , it 's quite well ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Try Pableine . It 's a wonderful restorative . I 'm intruding ——

div.stage: Looking round .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Not at all . We were just about to settle the question Mr. Barron raised last New Year 's day ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Oh , yes ; I remember ! Curiously enough I have only this morning received the proofs of my new volume , “ Free Will , the Illusion . ”

div.stage: Showing the proofs to PILCHER .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Very interesting . I should like to discuss the matter with you , buttaking out watchI have so many New Year 's calls to make .Looking at MATT .Perhaps we ought to get on with the — a ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Inquest .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Vindication .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Accepting the correction .Vindication .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Again offering the proof .I may perhaps be allowed to point out that Mr. Barron 's novel and humorous experiment can in no sense be said to settle , or even to touch , the question of Free Will , which as I have proved here depends upon ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: I should like to look through those sheets , but ——

div.stage: Glancing at MATT .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: You shall ! I have put the whole argument into the concrete case of Sarah Mumford ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Sarah Mumford ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: The baby farmer ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Sarah 's gray matter gone watery ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Not watery , but she had a yellow effusion ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I suppose that 's just as bad ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What did they do with her ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: They hanged her . They then discovered extensive lesions and this yellow effusion ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Pity they did n't discover that before they hanged her .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: My exact point ! Where is the justice of punishing a woman whose gray matter functions perversely ? It is nothing short of a crime .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: But she had suffocated five dear little babies ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: How could she avoid suffocating babies if she had a yellow effusion in her brain ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Precisely my argument ——

div.stage: Puts his proofs into MATT 'S hands . Points out a passage . MATT , a little embarrassed , takes them , looks through them .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: The point I wish to establish is this . While we all allow that extensive or recognizable diseases of , or injuries to , the brain , free a man from responsibility and punishment , how can we logically mete out blame or praise , punishment or reward to our ordinary acts , thoughts , and impulses , seeing that all our acts , thoughts , and impulses , good or bad , virtuous or criminal , are equally the mere expressions of certain inevitable physical changes in the brain , the mere register on the dial plate of consciousness of necessary predetermined complications in the working of certain atoms of the gray matter of our cortex ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Quite so ! Quite so !DOLLY is about to speak , but MATT hushes her down with a warning look and sign .The Professor wants to say with Socrates that no man would be such a fool as to do wrong , if he could possibly help it .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Well , if you like to put it that way ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: And now perhaps we might proceed . Can you remember the exact terms , Mr. Barron ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I am to pay a sovereign for everyone of your hearers who has so far benefited by the wise admonitions of your last year 's sermon as to have broken off his bad habits , or some especial bad habit ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: We are n't bound to say what the habit is that we 've broken off ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I do n't wish to be inquisitive , but if you do n't mention the particular bad habit , you will have to give me your word of honor that you 've conquered it .Putting down proofs on table , taking up the money-box , giving it a shake .Looking round .Now , who will be first to step into the confessional ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I will . As I 've nothing to confess .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Nothing ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No . I had what some husbands might think a bad habit , but ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No bills this Christmas , eh , Doll ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You 're sure now , my darling ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: None of any importance .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: What do you mean of any importance ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Well , you must have some bills — they grow up before you know — such as Doctors ’ bills — you can n't settle them all on the spur of the moment , but I 've nothing — nothing of importance . So please put in your sovereign for me , Dad , and look pleasant about it .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: You declare upon your word of honor that you have broken off your bad habit of running up bills ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Entirely ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes . You said you would n't be inquisitive .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Yes , but ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Mrs. Telfer has given her word . I think I may claim one victory for free will ,nodding victoriously at the PROFESSOR who shakes his head, and one sovereign for the Blanket Club .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Hum !Draws a sovereign out of his pocket and very reluctantly drops it into the box , shakes his head at DOLLY who looks a little uncomfortable .Who volunteers next ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I do . No — I 'll wait a little — I want to make sure that I am perfectly honest with myself and with everybody .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: That perhaps may need a little consideration , Lucas ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh , let Harry have his doing first !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Now , Harry !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , well , here goes ! I 'm going to make a clean breast . The fact is I 've made a thundering mess of it .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I did begin all right except for a little tiff with Dolly — and then I kept on pretty well for some time , and then — well I do n't know — I seemed to go all to pieces and —MATT rattles the money-box .However , better luck this year .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Shall we say a little more resolution ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Oh , I mean to pull myself together this year .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Perhaps you tried too much reforming , Harry — too many irons in the fire , eh ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Well , it 's jolly hard to keep it up . And I 'd got pretty slack till you woke us up last night — I say , that was a rouser again .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: It was n't a very bad sermon , was it ? Well now for the next year shall we make one especial effort in one especial direction — Say ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Temper , eh , Harry ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Right , old girl ! Oh , I mean it .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No victory for free will , and the Blanket Club , this time . Game and game , eh ? Now which of you two ——

div.stage: Looking at RENIE and LUCAS .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I 'll be your first victim .Coming into the middle of the room , and posing .It 's so strange that what you started as a jest ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Oh no , in deadly earnest I assure you .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: In this life who knows what is jest and what is earnest ? The least little innocent thing may turn to a tragedy in a moment ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Surely you have n't had any little tragedies ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: No , last year a mere little circumstance might have turned to a tragedy — honestly I was n't to blame , but perhaps I was a little careless , and two dear friends came to me with their counsel , and what might have been a tragedy was turned to a comedy , thanks to those two dear friends !

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: My dear , may I ask “ what circumstance ” you are alluding to ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: We said we would n't be inquisitive ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: No , but I cannot recall anything in my wife 's life during the last twelve months that even approached a tragedy ——

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I said the affair was quite unimportant ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Then I wish , my dear , you would n't magnify everything , and I wish you would read solid scientific works in place of rubbishy French novels — and above all , take a little more regular exercise !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Perhaps Mrs. Sturgess may consider that little point during the coming year . Meantime ,To RENIEmay we be confident your little tragedy is ended ——

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Oh yes , quite .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: We need n't ask its nature , but you give us your word of honor ?

div.stage: Looks at her very searchingly and speaking seriously .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Yes , my word of honor .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Another victory .

lg.stage: Looks searchingly at her , drops a sovereign in the box .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Coming cheerfully forward .My turn for the thumbscrew !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: You seem very cheerful about it .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes , I 'm going to make a jolly good show .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What particular bad habit have you conquered during the past year ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I do n't know that I 've conquered any one in particular , but I 've had a regular good go in all round , so altogether I can pat myself on the back .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: But I want to know one particular habit conquered — for instance , you were n't very careful what ladies you made love to , or how many of them at the same time ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I say , Uncle Matt , drop this ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: And a year or two ago you went just a little bit off the straight ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Oh no I did n't .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I want to know ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Thank you , no more thumbscrew . I 'm out of this before it goes any further .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: It is n't going any further .Putting his hand on LUCAS 'S shoulder .Give me your word of honor ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: That 's all very well , it was n't a very bad case , and I do n't think you should have brought it up . But as you have — well , I did meet a lady , and I was very much attracted to her , but I summoned all my resolution , and there the matter ended .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: I think I may claim a victory here .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: So please put in your sovereign .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Very seriously .If you will give me your word of honor that you have absolutely broken off ——

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes , yes , of course I have .

div.stage: MATT puts in a sovereign , hands the box to PILCHER .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Three victories and one draw out of four . Most satisfactory .Taking out watch .I must hurry off to the White House and see what they 're doing there .Rattling the box .Excellent results ! So excellent that I think I 'm justified in making you a little New Year 's gift .

div.stage: Going to his heap of brown-paper parcels .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: A New Year 's gift ! How kind of you ! To me ?

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Opening his parcel .To you and your husband . To your husband in particular , because , although he may have fallen a little short of perfection during the last year — like some of the rest of us — yet I feel sure that during this coming year —They have all been watching him curiously ; he has now opened the parcel and displays a very bright brand new collecting box , with Crookbury Blanket Club painted on it , in large letters . It is much larger than the hospital box .Giving it to DOLLY .My household regulator !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Who has shown considerable disappointment on the opening of the parcel .Crookbury Blanket Club ! Thank you so much , for Harry 's sake . Harry ! For you , dear .

div.stage: She gives the box to HARRY , who places it on the same table .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You call it the household regulator ?

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Yes — I have suggested it to several of my brethren . Oh , its use will become very general throughout the diocese .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You think it will work well ?

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: It cannot fail . A box of this character — larger or smaller , according to the size of the family and their behaviour is left at each house on the first of the year . All little failings , peccadilloes , and asperities are strictly fined . The inevitable result is that either the family behaviour improves , or the parish charities benefit . I 'm starting its operation in my parish to-day . Forgive any inexcusable rudeness in leaving the first box with you . I must hurry off !Shaking hands .Good-bye , Professor .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I should like to make that point clear with regard to free will ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: When you have an hour , or shall I say a year , to spare , we might argue it out ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: You 're going to the White House ? If I might accompany you ——

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Delighted !

div.stage: Shakes hands in dumb show with DOLLY and HARRY .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Renie , you 've had your restless fits again . You 'd better come with us ——

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: But I 've already been walking ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: My dear , this bracing country air is just what you need . Keep out in it all the day long ——

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Oh , very well — the White House , and the fish-pond as usual , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: As usual . Come along .

div.stage: Exit . RENIE slightly shrugs her shoulders , very slightly glances at LUCAS and exit after PROFESSOR .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: The dear old fish-pond ! We might all take a stroll there !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Good idea ! The dear old fish-pond ! We might all take a stroll there !

div.stage: Linking his arm with LUCAS .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Suspicious , holding back .I do n't know that I care — we went there last year ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: We did ! Same old game , eh ? Come along .

div.stage: Drags LUCAS off .

sp.speaker: Pilcher
sp.p: Has been gathering up his parcels .Well , good-bye ! Good-bye !Rattles the hospital box vigorously .Three splendid victories for free will and moral resolution !

div.stage: Exit , rattling the box .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Doll , you really have n't got any bills this year ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No ! no ! Only the few little oddments that no woman can prevent .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: You might let me see the little oddments ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I will .Suddenly .Oh Harry , I quite forgot ! Do forgive me !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I never wrote the geyser bath people !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Never mind the geyser bath .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: And only this morning you rowed me because I had n't got it ready for the New Year ! Where did you put their address ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I do n't know ! Somewhere upstairs among my papers .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Gently pushing him off .I can just catch to-night 's post ! Make haste and get it ! Quick ! There 's a dear ! And then we can get the bath fixed up for you next week .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Ye — es . I say , Doll , I mean to get those oddments fixed up to-night .

div.stage: Taps the writing-case significantly and exit . DOLLY looks frightened , sees him off , goes up to writing-desk , takes out bills , looks at them , throws up her arms in despair , groans , slams down the writing-desk , looks at the chair she has touched in first act , shows great resolution , marches up and touches it .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ! Yes ! I have got free will .

div.stage: Goes back from it , again looks at it , again marches up to it , touches it .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Then why do I keep on having bills ? RENIE enters in great agitation and distress .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Oh , Dolly !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Oh , Dolly !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Throws her arms round DOLLY affectionately .You 've always been such a true friend to me ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes , dear .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: More like a sister . And I know I may trust you now .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: A little suspicious .Yes . Has anything happened ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Yes . Oh , Dolly ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Tell me !

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: As we were going out at the garden gate , Captain Wentworth held out a letter behind his back for me to take ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What ? !

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: But now his arm is wounded he could n't manage it properly , and he dropped it . I hurried to pick it up , and then my husband noticed and insisted on reading it ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What was in the letter ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: It was n't so very bad , but my husband has chosen to jump to a wrong conclusion , and — oh , Dolly , you can help me !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Coldly , relaxing her embrace .How ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: If you 'd only let me tell my husband that I was receiving it for you ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What ? !

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: There was no address , and fortunately it was so worded that it showed that you were n't really guilty .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Oh ! I was n't really guilty ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: In fact , it proves your complete innocence .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I 'm glad of that .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Then you 'll let me say it was you ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No ! You can n't suppose I should let my own cousin make love to me in my own house ? !

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: You wo n't help me ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes , any way but that ! How could you be so foolish ?

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: I do n't know . When I heard yesterday he was coming , I quite made up my mind I 'd have nothing to say to him ! Dolly , free will must be an illusion , or else why am I always doing the things I do n't mean to do . Oh , what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: As you are completely innocent , you 'd better ask your husband to forgive you .

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Ye — es . No ! As it is a perfectly pure and exalted attachment I shall take that ground — at any rate at first , and see what he says . You 'll help me all you can ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes , but promise me you 'll have nothing to do with Lucas in future !

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: No , indeed ! if I once get out of this .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Very well ! I 'll see what I can do .— Hush ! The PROFESSOR enters with a letter in his hand , MATT soothing him .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Very angry .Not a word more , if you please . Mrs. Telfer , you have doubtless heard ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ——?

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I leave for London to-night-to consult my lawyer . Mrs. Sturgess will , I trust , return to her friends until ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Perhaps Mrs. Sturgess may be able to explain ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: What explanation can be offered of language like this .Reading from letter .“ From the first moment I saw you , I felt that you were entirely different from any woman I have ever met —— ” A monstrously inexact statement to start with . And a woman who is capable of practising such deceit ——

div.stage: RENIE bursts into tears .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I think you ought to hear what Mrs. Sturgess has to say ——

sp.speaker: Renie
sp.p: Through her tears .What would be the use ? With such a nature as his he could never begin to understand the loyal and exalted devotion which Captain Wentworth feels for me ! No , all my life I have been misunderstood , misjudged , condemned ! Let it be so till the end ! Dolly , come and help me pack !

div.stage: Exit . MATT goes up to table and takes up proofs of PROFESSOR 'S book and looks through them .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You 're really too severe with poor Renie ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I am not severe . I simply register the inevitable sentence of the husband upon the wife who misconducts herself !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Misconducts herself ! She has merely had a little harmless flirtation ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: In my wife a flirtation of this characterpointing to letter in his handconstitutes grave misconduct .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: But that 's perfectly ridiculous ! Why it might happen to any woman ! Dad , explain to him ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Professor , you 're taking altogether a wrong view of this . Now this case you were pointing out to me in your own bookpointing to proofs— Number forty-nine , Mrs. Copway . Remarkably handsome woman too !—reading“ The injustice and cruelty of condemning this poor lady must be apparent to all . ” My dear Professor , before publishing this book you 'll have to modify your theory .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I cannot modify my theory . I have spent ten years in collecting facts which prove it .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Then , pardon me , you must really look over Mrs. Sturgess 's little indiscretion .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: That is equally impossible ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: But you say that her action in receiving my nephew 's letter was entirely due to the activity of certain atoms in the gray matter of her brain .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Undoubtedly that is so .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Very well then , if her gray matter keeps on working wrong , what 's the use of blaming her ? You say yourself there 's no such thing as free will ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Precisely , but I have always allowed that in the present low moral and intellectual condition of the herd of mankind , free will is a plausible working hypothesis .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: But it does n't work ! Free will wo n't work at all ! Look at my own case ! Do you suppose I should go on all my life having bills if I could help myself ?Catching MATT 'S eye , who looks at her gravely and holds up his finger .Never mind my bills ! Do make him see how wrong and absurd it is to punish poor Renie when there 's no such thing as free will !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Dolly 's right ! She 's only saying what you have so admirably laid down here . My dear Professor , you cannot possibly publish this book !

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: But it has been announced ! I must publish it .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: You cannot . Read that .Giving the PROFESSOR the book and pointing out passage .Surely after that you cannot condemn Mrs. Sturgess .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Taking book , glancing at the passage .Really , it 's most annoying when one 's own wife upsets ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Oh ! they 're always making hay of our theories one way or the other .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Of course , if one presses the matter home to first principles ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ! Yes ! Well , why not act on your own first principles ! You ought to be very sorry for poor Renie , considering all she has suffered .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Suffered ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes , poor dear ! You do n't know what an awful struggle she has gone through between this unfortunate flirtation and her admiration for you .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Her admiration for me !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes ! She always speaks of you as her great protagonist of science .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Mollified .Does she ? Does she ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes . If I were you I should go upstairs , and be very sweet to her , and above all do n't reproach her . We women can endure anything except reproaches ——

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Looking at his proofs .I must publish my book . And after all , as you say , it is useless to blame them for acting according to the ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: The dictates of their gray matter when , bless them , they can n't help themselves . My dear Professor , instead of condemning your wife you ought to be condoling with her , and doing all you can to get her gray matter into a healthy condition .

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: I will hear what she has to say .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No . Go straight to her and forgive her , and then I 'm sure her gray matter will soon be all right . And what a triumph that will be for you !

sp.speaker: Prof
sp.p: Exit .It does offer a way out of the difficulty . In any case I must publish my book .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Dad , I wo n't have her here next Christmas .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No , my dear , I would n't .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: That wretched Lucas !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What is to be done with him ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Pack him off ! Pack him off at once !

div.stage: LUCAS cautiously looks in from upper conservatory door .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I say , how 's the old bird seem to take it ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Old bird !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: He is n't going to make a shindy over a trifle like this ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Trifle ! He 's threatening to divorce her and expose you !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: You do n't say so . I 'm awfully sorry !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Sorry !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: I am , indeed ! And any reparation I can make ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Reparation ? !

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Such as an apology ——

div.stage: DOLLY utters a contemptuous exclamation .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Will you give me your word of honor never to see Mrs. Sturgess again ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Or write to her ?

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: The word of honour of an English gentleman used to mean something , Lu .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: It does now , Uncle Matt !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Shakes hands with him heartily .Then I 'll take it . Now be off as quickly as you can and let us make the best of it for you and her .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Thanks . Good-bye !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Good-bye !

div.stage: LUCAS crosses to DOLLY , offers his hand .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: No , Lu . If Renie gets out of this safely and if you behave yourself , I 'll shake hands with you when you come back from India .

sp.speaker: Lucas
sp.p: Exit .You 're taking this too seriously — you 're taking it far too seriously !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: We 're making a splendid start again for the New Year !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I hope this will be a lesson for Renie !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I hope so . How about yourself ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I put the sovereign in , but — you 've got a few more bills , eh ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Just a few oddments .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: How much ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I do n't know . Dad ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Now that South Africans have gone up at last , and you won that splendid coup on them last week ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You could n't lend me — a few hundreds — till my allowance comes due ? Just a few hundreds ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: In a low reproachful tone , shaking his head .What ? What ? What ? Sad ! Sad ! Sad ! !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Listens .There 's Harry ! You will help me , Dad — you will ?

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: I 'll see what I can do . HARRY enters cheerfully .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: That 's all right , Doll ! There 's the address .

div.stage: Giving a slip of paper .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Thanks , dear .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: And now about these mere oddments ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Not now , dear .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes , dear , now .Very sternly .This instant !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Harry , you 're going to lose your temper ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No . I 'm going to keep a firm guard on it , butvery sternlylet me see those bills .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Creeps frightened up to the desk .I 'm sure you 're going to lose your temper .

div.stage: Opens the desk .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Firmly .No . I 'm quite calm . Whose bill is that ?She hands him one timorously .Fulks and Garner ! Artist Furriers ! More artists !looks at total— one hundred and twenty-four pounds . Well , I 'm ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Ah , Jobling !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I should think I am Jobling . And you said you 'd never enter their shop again !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I never meant it , but this time it was absolutely necessary ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Necessary ?

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Yes — you see the chief item ——

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Reads .Chinchilla toque , coat , muff and boa — eighty guineas — eighty guineas ——

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: I got them as a surprise for you when we go South next week .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Surprise ! Great heavens ! What in the name of all ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Shush , Harry ! Her motive was a good one . She got it to please you !

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: You have n't seen it yet , it 's just outside — I 've a great mind to give you a great New Year 's treat and let you see it on !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I 'm not going to be sweedled ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Exit DOLLY .Hush ! Harry ! Let her put it on ! Let 's have a look at it , and see whether it 's worth the money . Put it on , Doll .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Calls after her .I tell you I 'm not going to be sweedled !——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: What is sweedled ?

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Sweedling is sweedling ! It 's part swindling and part wheedling ! It 's what every d — ee — d good-natured husband like me has to go through , when he 's fool enough to put up with it !

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: Well , old boy , you 'll have to pay , you know ; it will come to that in the end .

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: I 'm not going to be sweedled ——

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: And if Dolly has been a little extravagant , I must help her out with it to-morrow morning !

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: No , we 'll go into it thoroughly to-night .

sp.speaker: Matt
sp.p: No , Harry , we wo n't . My room is just above here . Besides , the cook is going to give us a special New Year dinner , and I want to enjoy it . This New Year we 'll start with a comfortable evening , please ! DOLLY enters at back in a very handsome Chinchilla coat . HARRY looks a little sulky . She stands in the middle of the room and displays it .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Well ?He looks at it rather sulkily , walks away ; she follows him .Well ?Walking after him .Well ? Well ?

div.stage: Displaying the furs .
He turns , looks at her , she stands and holds out her arms .

lg.stage: Takes her in his arms and kisses her .

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: Kissing him heartily .And there !Another kiss .And there !Another kiss .And there !Catches sight of the collecting box , goes to it , furiously sweeps it off its table on to the floor .AND THERE !

div.stage: CURTAIN .
